details:
libssh security advisories:

> The SSH protocol keeps track of two shared secrets during the lifetime
> of the session. One of them is called `secret\_hash` and and the other
> `session\_id`. Initially, both of them are the same, but after key
> re-exchange, previous `session\_id` is kept and used as an input to new
> `secret\_hash`.
>
> Historically, both of these buffers had shared length variable, which
> worked as long as these buffers were same. But the key re-exchange
> operation can also change the key exchange method, which can be based on
> hash of different size, eventually creating `secret\_hash` of different
> size than the `session\_id` has.
>
> This becomes an issue when the `session\_id` memory is zeroized or when
> it is used again during second key re-exchange.
